title: Music publisher coalition sues Twitter over copyright
author: Kenan Draughorne
excerpt: Seventeen music publishers are suing Twitter, accusing the company of refusing to licence the millions of songs on its service.
summary:
A coalition of music publishers, including Universal Music Publishing Group, Warner Chappell Music and Sony Music Publishing, is suing Twitter over "massive copyright infringement" involving the companies' respective music catalogues.
Seventeen music publishers, who hold the rights to music from artists including Drake, Taylor Swift and Adele, filed the joint lawsuit on Wednesday in Tennessee federal court. They seek more than $US250 million ($A368 million) in damages.
Elon Musk's X Corp, which owns Twitter, is the sole defendant.

, Indonesian music is a rich tapestry of sounds, rhythms, and melodies, a reflection of the country's diverse cultural heritage. The music of Indonesia is as varied as the many islands that make up the archipelago. It is a musical journey that takes listeners from the traditional gamelan orchestras of Java to the vibrant pop music of Jakarta, from the haunting sounds of the bamboo angklung to the hypnotic rhythms of dangdut, a popular music genre that blends elements of traditional Indonesian music with Middle Eastern and Indian influences.

title: World Music Day 2023: History, significance and quotes to share on social media
author: India Today Information Desk
excerpt: World Music Day 2023: Check out its history, significance, quotes that you can on WhatsApp and Facebook status.
summary:
World Music Day, also known as Fête de la Musique, is an annual global celebration of music that is observed on June 21. The day is celebrated to honor the musicians and singers for the gift of music, which gives flight to the imagination and life to everything.
For many, the world would be meaningless without music, so World Music Day is celebrated to celebrate its power. Music is a vital part of everyday life, and World Music Day marks the importance of music every year.
Every year, more than 120 countries celebrate World Music Day.

title: Philadelphia music program celebrates 10 years of empowering youth
author: Wakisha Bailey
excerpt: The after-school program, Music Education Pathways, has served over 1,200 students at 14 different schools throughout Philadelphia.
summary:
PHILADELPHIA (CBS) - On this week's Focusing On The Future, a local music education program is celebrating 10 years of empowering Philadelphia youth to think outside the box.

"I play trumpet," said 5th grader Saffron Cuarezma said. "When I play my music I just get into the music and I don't think about what's going on around me."

Ten-year-old Saffron has been playing the trumpet for two years. This shiny gold instrument is an expression of self.

"You have this opportunity to play an instrument for two days a week," said Saffron

"We have flute, clarinet, saxophone, trumpet, trombone, percussion, drums for anybody else," said Band Director of Music Education Pathways Jordan Graef.

title: 'Our Chicago: Freedom Music' celebrates Juneteenth 2023 and the power of Black music
author: Cheryl Burton
excerpt: Black Americans have felt the freedom to express themselves through music long before Juneteenth 1865.
summary:
By
Cheryl Burton
 and 
Terrell Brown
 
Sunday, June 18, 2023 10:14PM
CHICAGO (WLS) -- 
"Our Chicago: Freedom Music" is a dynamic celebration of freedom expressed through the music of Chicago's Black community as part of ABC7's Juneteenth celebration.
Black Americans have felt the freedom to express themselves through music long before Juneteenth 1865. From African drums, spirituals, gospel to blues, house and hip hop, Black Americans have used music to celebrate the joys of life and help get through the tough times too.

title: Twitter sued for $250m over music copyright violations

excerpt: Elon Musk's photo is seen through a Twitter logo - DADO RUVIC/REUTERSElon Musk's Twitter has been sued for $250m (£198m) by music publishers for hundreds of alleged copyright breaches.In claims filed…
summary:
Elon Musk's Twitter has been sued for $250m (£198m) by music publishers for hundreds of alleged copyright breaches.
In claims filed in the US, 17 music publishers, including Sony and Universal Music, claimed Twitter 'fuels its business with countless infringing copies of musical compositions'.
The music industry's row with Twitter pre-dates Mr Musk's $44bn takeover, although the publishers claim the social media company has been in 'disarray' since the deal went through.
The claims name Mr Musk's X Corp, which owns Twitter, as the defendant.

summary:

Settling a new puppy can be a challenge, and some pets don't do great with being left home alone. Fireworks, car rides, thunderstorms, trips to the vet or grooming sessions may cause your pet to feel uneasy. Relaxing sounds from a musical playlist can help.

A 2017 study conducted by the University of Glasgow and Scottish SPCA highlighted how kenneled dogs' stress levels drop when they listen to reggae or soft rock.

title: 'Music was my sister's soul': Des Moines music scene mourns death of super fan Wendy Hull
author: Paris Barraza
summary:
Members of the Des Moines music scene are mourning Wendy Hull, an ardent supporter of local musicians and the music community, who died Monday.
Hull, 52, is behind the 
Facebook group Wednesday's Notes
, where she posted lists of upcoming performances, promoted events and published interviews with musicians. It has more than 2,700 followers.
Hull also frequently attended shows in Des Moines.
'Wendy was like the local music scene super fan,' Mickey Davis, Des Moines Music Coalition executive director, told the Des Moines Register in a phone call Wednesday.

'Wendy was like the local music scene super fan,' Mickey Davis, Des Moines Music Coalition executive director, told the Des Moines Register in a phone call Wednesday.

title: 17 Music Publishers Sue Twitter for Copyright Infringement
author: Matthew Humphries
excerpt: The lawsuit claims Twitter 'breeds massive copyright infringement that harms music creators.'
summary:
Twitter is being sued by a group of 17 music publishers for allowing users to share music on its platform without a license.

As Reuters reports(Opens in a new window), the lawsuit(Opens in a new window) seeks a trial by jury and damages in excess of $250 million, which is based on the service allegedly infringing nearly 1,700 copyrights. The publishers involved in this suit include two of the biggest names in the music business, notably Sony Music Publishing and Universal Music Publishing Group.

title: AI Won't Kill the Music. Buy Universal and Warner Stock.

excerpt: Fears of AI are weighing on the shares of Universal Music and Warner Music, but that is overdone.
summary:
Illustration by Lynne Carty/Barron's 
 
 
 
In April, a catchy new duet was uploaded to music-streaming services by an anonymous user. Listeners who tuned in heard Drake's voice pumping through their headphones, crooning, 'I got my heart on my sleeve with a knife in my back. What's with that?' Fellow megastar The Weeknd seemed to agree with Drake's romantic struggles. His voice cried out, 'I put her in the past.'
 
The two Canadian singers may have been telling the truth about love, but their supposed collaboration wasn't technically real.

title: Music helps to boost confidence and improves social interaction among millennials in India: JBL survey

excerpt: According to the survey, the Bollywood music genre emerged as the top choice with a 37 percent of the respondents selecting this as their favourite genre.
summary:
A large number of music lovers in acknowledge the de-stressing and relaxing effects of music while many believe that listening to music boosts their confidence, according to a survey by American audio equipment manufacturer JBL. The company, known for its speakers and earbuds, conducts a survey every year on the occasion of Music Day, which is celebrated on June 21, to understand the music consumption habits of the people.
The survey was conducted by JBL to determine the emergence of music consumption patterns among ns.

title: Make Music Day comes back to Salem in full-force on June 21
author: Kristian Foden-Vencil
excerpt: After a couple of anemic Make Music days in Salem during the pandemic, this year's event looks set to return to its pre-COVID size.
summary:
Members of the Sprague High School Orchestra perform on Make Music Salem at the Gerry Frank Salem Rotary Amphitheater. June 21, 2022
Ron Cooper
After a couple of anemic Make Music days in Salem during the pandemic, this year's event looks set to return to its pre-COVID size.
Over 1,000 cities across the world are scheduled to celebrate 
Make Music Day
 on the first day of summer, June 21.
In Salem alone, 165 artists will perform at over 50 locations. Make Music Salem co-founder Mark Green says music is a way to bring everyone together.

title: Algonquin native piano teacher given national Teacher of the Year award
author: Michelle Meyer
excerpt: Algonquin native and Harper College piano teacher Dr. Janice Larson Razaq named 2023 Teacher of the Year by the Music Teachers National Association
summary:
Algonquin
 native Dr. Janice Larson Razaq has been named the 2023 Teacher of the Year by the Music Teachers National Association.
The Music Teachers National Association is the oldest music teacher organization in the county, being founded 1876. The nonprofit organization supports and helps music teachers grow professionally.
Razaq, an Algonquin resident, is the director of Keyboard Studies at Harper College in Palatine, where she has been teaching since the 1970s. She teaches individual and group piano lessons to anyone ages 6 to 80 at Harper College's Community Music Center.

title: Twitter hit with $250 million copyright infringement lawsuit from music publishers
author: Kenan Draughorne
excerpt: Seventeen music publishers, who hold the rights to songs from artists including Drake, Taylor Swift and Adele, seek over $250 million in damages.
summary:
A coalition of music publishers, including Universal Publishing Group, Warner Chappell and Sony Publishing, is suing Twitter over 'massive copyright infringement' involving the companies' respective music catalogs.

Seventeen music publishers, who hold the rights to music from artists including Drake, Taylor Swift and Adele, filed the joint lawsuit in Tennessee federal court. They seek more than $250 million in damages.

Elon Musk's X Corp, which owns Twitter, is the sole defendant.

'Twitter stands alone as the largest social media platform that has completely refused to license the millions of songs on its service,' David Israelite, chief executive of the National Publishers' Assn.
authors: Kenan Draughorne,Kenan DraughorneStaff Writer,Staff Writer,Was A Member,ter At The Los Angeles Times

title: Garth Brooks launches global country music radio station The BIG 615
author: Angeline Jane Bernabe
excerpt: Garth Brooks talks about his new global country music radio station.
summary:
Garth Brooks is taking country music to a global audience.

On Thursday, the country music legend is launching The BIG 615, a new radio station that will give listeners an "authentic take on country music that offers up the biggest songs and the biggest artists today," according to a press release.

"What we want to do is we want to take country music global," Brooks told "Good Morning America." "The country music audience [is the] most loving, loyal audience you can ever have. We pull all them together around the world.

title: Ballantine's Scotch Whisky Unveils Recipients of its 2023 True Music Fund
author: info@hypebeast.com
excerpt: Supporting grassroots music communities.
summary:
Ballantine's
 relationship with music is deep-rooted. Having launched its 
'True Music Series'
 back in 2014 to provide a platform for diverse artists and promote inclusive music experiences, the Scotch whisky brand introduced its True Music Fund in 2021 after witnessing small organizations — especially the live music scene — struggling to stay afloat after the pandemic.


Recognizing the role brands must play in supporting emerging collectives striving for equality in the industry, Ballantine's pledged an annual six-figure funding plan for music initiatives worldwide to encourage grassroots change.
authors: Ali Mohammed-Ali,Dylan Kelly,Eric Brain,Hb Team,Jack Lynch,Zoe Leung,info@hypebeast.com

summary:
Music isn't just for entertainment. Having it on in the background can 
help you focus better
, even if you struggle with 
attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
.
 
But with music and people being so diverse, how do you decide which is best for you? 
Researchers have found
 that when it comes to boosting brainpower, there is no one-fits-all genre.
 
It entirely depends on the individual and what they respond to. I have many favorites — hip-hop, rap, pop, country, folk, classical, opera. So it's not about genre for me.

title: Music on the Inside: ‘It gave me a second chance'
author: Magee Hickey
excerpt: UPPER WEST SIDE, Manhattan (PIX11) — It was a Juneteenth Jazz jubilee like no other. Formerly incarcerated men were up on the stage at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, showing everyo…
summary:
UPPER WEST SIDE, Manhattan () — It was a Juneteenth Jazz jubilee like no other.
 
Formerly incarcerated men were up on the stage at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, showing everyone in the audience how music can change people's lives.
 
One of them was Chontay Smith. He sounds and plays like a professional musician; instead, he hopes to inspire others to turn to music to turn their lives around.
 
The 48-year-old was serving 25 years in prison for a drug offense when he joined the Music on the Inside program.

title: Prince, music estates, and the ethics of posthumously releasing music

summary:
Opinion: Part four of theGrio's four-part series on Prince engages in discourse about the moral dilemma when it comes to music estates dropping unreleased music of deceased artists.
Editor's note: The following article is an op-ed and the views expressed are the author's own. Read more opinions on theGrio.
Prince's catalog of music was vast that only his unreleased music could compete with it. One of the most mythical aspects of Prince's story is his infamous vault. Following his death, it was reported that his estate could conceivably release albums of unheard music for 100 years.

 is a go-to platform for many music lovers, as it offers a wide range of music from different genres and artists globally.
